title: Who will be elected governor of Missouri in 2020?
preds: "Parson has been hurt by sagging support for President Donald Trump in Missouri; Trump won the state by 18 points in 2016 but leads in recent polls by only about six points. Parson has also taken some fire for his handling of the coronavirus pandemic. He faces Democratic state auditor Nicole Galloway. We are keeping Missouri at Lean Republican." https://www.usnews.com/news/elections/articles/2020-10-29/analysis-republicans-maintain-edge-in-governor-races
Polling quality is not great in Missouri but Republicans seem to have a slender lead. [1] [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/missouri/

While a couple polls have been closer, Parson continues to win in every one of them. Incumbency, state history, and current support are all skewed in the GOP's favor here. Unlikely to change before the election.

Moving more into the Galloway bucket with some recent polls.  And, the fact that everyone assumes Missouri will follow Trump has left enthusiasm for voting lower than other states.  Parson seems worried and Republicans have initiated a smear campaign against Galloway.   If Democrats turn out in mass and Republicans think Trump is a shoe in stay home, Missouri could still pull off some surprises.

"Parson, a longtime legislator, ascended to the governorship after Republican Eric Greitens resigned in June 2018 amid allegations of sexual misconduct. In 2020, he's seeking a term in his own right against Democratic challenger Nicole Galloway, the state auditor. In recent elections, Missouri has shifted to the right, but Republican weakness in the suburbs has cut Trump’s margins in recent polls, and to some extent, those trends have also hurt Parson. Meanwhile, Galloway has been a strong fundraiser for a red-state Democratic challenger, enabling her to spend heavily on TV ads. Parson’s ratings for handling the coronavirus haven’t been stellar by the standards of other governors, and in late September, he announced that he and his wife had contracted the virus. If the Democrats are to win, they will need big turnout in Kansas City and St. Louis. Four polls starting in mid-August have shown Parson leading Galloway by between seven and 15 percentage points, but a late-September internal poll for Galloway’s campaign showed her trailing by just two points. We’re keeping this race at Lean Republican." https://www.usnews.com/news/elections/articles/2020-10-13/analysis-republicans-look-poised-to-maintain-edge-in-governors-mansions
Parson holds double digit leads in most of the latest polls. Trump is leading Biden here by a wide margin as well. Hard to see this state turning blue.
Parson continues to be up big in all polls. Reps should have this seat in the bag.

From a Cook Political report update out today: "The only race that has shown significant movement in the past few months is in Missouri, where Republican Gov. Mike Parson is seeking a full term in his own right after being elevated to the office in 2018. Parson faces a strong challenge from state Auditor Nicole Galloway, the only remaining statewide Democratic elected official in Missouri. Several factors, including increased spending from both national Republican and Democratic groups, along with strong fundraising from Galloway, competitive internal polling, newly up-for-grabs suburban areas and miscues on COVID from Parsons make this a more competitive race, and we are moving Missouri from Likely to Lean Republican." https://cookpolitical.com/analysis/governors/governors-overview/governors-updates-rating-changes-missouri-and-vermont
Mike Parson remains very popular in the state.
Dems lose here by a large margin.
Galloway is down in the polls following the Primary. More importantly, Parson started wearing a mask.

Close race. Parson has law enforcement background. Galloway's background is in finance. If the economy was in a boom state - she would have a better shot; young & change could be her platform. However, I believe Parson will continue as Governor.

Up-ballot lead for Trump has been steadily increasing in the last month, which will likely be reflected in the voter turnout and support for the Republican candidate (Parson). While he has given up a relatively large lead, no official polls on this race have been posted since July 13th, which is almost the exact date Trump began to regain his lead in the presidential polling.

OK, here is a link to the primary results. 
https://enr.sos.mo.gov/ With an open primary (could vote in any party) 680,310 voted Republican and 535,676 voted on the Democrat ticket.  Two key numbers: 
Parson only took 75% of the Republican Vote, or 510,000 votes out of 680,000
Galloway took 84.6% of the Democrat Vote, or 453,000 votes out of 535,000.  That leaves 80,000 Democrats who likely will follow Galloway, and 170,000 Republicans who voted against Parson in the Primary. The key question is whether they are angry enough to switch parties.   Parson (and the Republican party) was firmly against Medicaid Expansion, which is why the voters went around them and put it on the ballot. It passed 672,000 - 590,000. So, 90,000 voters crossed party lines on this issue.  Another key result is that among the Republicans who didn’t vote for Parson, 12% or 83,000 voted for McDowell, also a female, and the most left of the Republicans. This is comparable to the 90,000 who crossed the party line on Medicare.  Assuming the remaining voters stay solid with Parson, this puts Galloway back where she was at the beginning of this question, according to FiveThirtyEight, in a statistical dead heat. Missouri is one of the latest hot spots for Corona Virus, and Parson refuses to wear a mask, much less require one. He has insisted children return to school, and will likely be blamed for outbreaks.  I want to see some post primary polls, but  have increased my Galloway (Democrat) likelihood slightly. In Pettis County, where I live, a Republican stronghold, the relationship bears out. Parson took 5,030 of 5,842 Republican votes vs 5,437 who voted no on Medicare. McDowell only had 2% of the vote, or 114.
Dead heat based on recent polling.  Trumps numbers are lower at present than in 2016.

Still staying the same (waiting till primary Tuesday), but thought I would share a background link on the race if any of you want one.  https://www.courthousenews.com/coronavirus-response-could-see-shake-up-in-missouri-governors-race/ While they are currently neck in neck, after the primary is over, and the focus is on the two candidates, it will be interesting to see how this plays out. Governor Parsons has made a few cringe worthy faux pas in the last few weeks, and Missouri has been spiking in cases. At the same time, he did well early in the pandemic, setting up systems to be in place now that it has arrived full force.

Parson is an incumbent, but he has given up a 13 point lead since early May. Now, the contest is basically a toss-up, and his contender, Galloway, has all the momentum. He's gaining in name recognition and popularity and the national trends are shifting towards his party.
Missouri being a mostly white state that has gone republican, will continue its trend. It also has a much lower non white population than the average US state
Missouri always votes Republican. Most of the people I know still seem to be leaning Republican
Based on alignment with presidential elections and backed by handling in uptick of covid.
Over the past few presidential elections, the MO governor has been aligned with the party of the president-elect.
This will be a year for a solid Democratic win on the national level to result in downballot victories.
Taking a conservative, but decisive stance in line with my previous forecast.

As long as Missouri doesn't have a huge outbreak when their kids go back to school (per Parsons orders), the current undecided voters will come back home to the Republican party. Missouri is not a blue state.
The country is at odds with itself. We can go either way and not be better off. The 15% choice is the best choice.
The Republican incumbent is ahead in the polls as of 7/21/2020
Overwhelmingly Republican state but Trump falling by historic margin, so a Democrat could win.
Given Parson is the incumbent and has not lost  poll to Galloway since January, hard to see him losing.

https://www.news-leader.com/story/news/politics/2020/07/19/coronavirus-missouri-covid-19-masks/5458502002/ https://www.ozarksfirst.com/local-news/regional-news/missouri-receives-15-million-in-cares-act-funding-to-help-rebuild-tourism-industry/ https://www.ksdk.com/article/news/local/missouri-governor-mike-parson-covid19-civil-unrest-briefing/63-ec6e38ac-225b-4db2-8ccc-e220da9013f5 https://news.google.com/articles/CAIiEPQuFMDKfOYykYPK31hguIwqFQgEKg0IACoGCAowrqkBMKBFMJGBAg?hl=en-US&gl=US&ceid=US%3Aen Given his behavior, I am going to make a move toward Galloway, who is in a dead heat.

The latest Missouri polls have Parson only up by 2 points: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/governor/missouri/ In recent years, the Governor seat has been pretty split between D/R.   In 2016, Trump won Missouri by 20 points, although 538 only has Trump's lead in the state by 4 points.
Switched around my answers! This is based on a Monte Carlo using the latest poll results.

YouGov (rated "B" by Five ThirtyEight) has it as anyone's race with Republican Mike Parson up by 2 among likely voters. [1] [1] https://www.slu.edu/research/research-institute/big-ideas/slu-poll/june-2020-poll/parson-galloway.php

Parson is up by about 6 points (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/governor/mo/missouri_governor_parson_vs_galloway-7202.html) & Trump is leading Biden by about 7 points (https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/mo/missouri_trump_vs_biden-7210.html) It looks like the votes will show up Republican here.

State leans red, and gop in lead in polls for gov race.   But not by much. Trump has a bigger lead over Biden than gop gov candidate has over dem.  Makes me think they don’t care for the gop candidate that much.  If Dems have a strong election, trump could win, but gop gov candidate could lose
I think there will be a protest vote against the incumbent but not enough to remove him
Eric Greitens resignation to avoid felony charges in June 2018 will make it very hard for the GOP to win the gubernatorial race.

One of the deepest red states, current governor is popular enough and consistently ahead in polls: https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/missouri/
Claire McCaskill declined to run, so this one will be fairly straightforward.
Taking an aggressive stance vs the crowd, will need more research: https://www.270towin.com/2020-governor-election/
This is a red state and not likley to flip blue.
Civil unrest in Missouri will cause some Republican seats to be lost to Dems.
First SWAG, based on initial review of the polls and my limited understanding of politics in the Show Me State.

This is a close race to call. Right now I am leaning towards the democrat Galloway. The polls do show the republican Parsons with a slight lead, but it a statistical dead heat. In one poll a large portion of African American voters were undecided, and African Americans by and large vote democrat.

I am providing input asa citizen of the state. The primary is the first week of August.  Traditionally Urban areas have voted Democrat. Rural have gone Republican. Parsons (presumptive Republican) has been playing to the strong Republican Rural base. Limits on Absentee ballots, no masks (Won’t wear one), just revoked helmet law for motorcycles, strong anti abortion and first and second amendment rights. And yes, opposed to protests.   Although he inherited the job as Governor, he has a strong base because of these stands. In addition, he has ensured PPP equipment and worked hard to make Missouri more ready.  The question in Missouri is if these stands will outweigh the massive number of cases of Covid caused by early reopening in coloring public perception. Unless a strong Democratic contender comes from the Democrat side in August, his popularity will likely carry a win for him.  I will look again after the primary.
